page.title: 15CONSERVATION AT HARNHILL
page.content: The removal of hedges in response to Government encouragement to increase food production in the 1940's, lessened the available habitat for the natural fauna. Plans now exist and are being implemented for the re-establishment of these hedges, and the replacement of trees lost to the ravages of Dutch Elm Disease.New ponds have also been created and there is now a greater number of these than in the past 100 years. Harnhill supports a surprising number of species of birds, mammals and insects considering it is one of the most modern and progressive farms in Gloucestershire. It combines efficient farming methods, with a broad minded commitment to conservation. Habitat varies from cereal, grass and some roots, to ten small woodlands, hedges and a short stretch of the Ampney Brook.
